title: How can Apple get away with saying everyone already has a charging block when they are shipping the new iPhone with USB C? The only iPhones that shipped with that are the 11 Pro. - Quora

response.answer_text: Apple’s pretty much expecting today’s new iPhone 12 user to already be an iPhone user, Macintosh user, or iPad user. If you have owned an iPhone or iPad since 2012, you already have a power brick (aka, charging block, charger, etc… it’s not actually a charger, but that’s what everyone calls it) with a Lightning cable and you don’t even need the Type-C to Lightning cable in the box. If you have a recent Macintosh or an iPad Pro, the cable in the box will let you charge from a Macintosh or a Macintosh/iPad Pro power brick, both of which use USB Type C. What’s maybe not being said is that you’re supposed to either trade in that old iPhone or toss it out. So you don’t need a new power brick, you can use the one from your old phone. Apple claiming that leaving out the power brick is for the environment is pretty rich coming from Apple. After all, their unreplaceable battery, their unserviceable cases, their fighting against right-to-repair laws, their all-glass cases, etc. are all aimed at making the iPhone relatively short-lived, a thing you replace every year or two, not a thing that lasts for years, not a thing you can as easily sell used or give to a kid when you’re done with it. How does Apple get away with this? The same way they get away with non-replaceable batteries, USB 2.0-only interfacing, no video output, proprietary connectors, small batteries, high prices, huge profits, no headphone jack, no fingerprint reader, only 12 megapixel cameras, etc… they’re Apple. They’re the only company that makes iPhones. You get what you get and you don’t get upset, or you jump over to Android, which may be a tall hill to climb for people who like Apple. And just to be fair, yes, leaving the power dongle and earbuds out of the box is a good thing for the environment, it’s just the one that probably makes an additional billion or two dollars for Apple in the process. Rather than, say, making the phone out of things that don’t smash to bits when they drop, or building in a battery that lasts two days. But this will go beyond Apple, because once Apple gets away with it, you can expect others to follow.  Another factor: saving money. Apple does love their high smartphone profit margins. This year, though, they didn’t raise the prices, but they did include a 5G-NR cellular modem, the Qualcomm X55. But that’s actually less of an issue than you might think. Qualcomm and other traditional telecom manufacturers have long ago integrated cellular modems into their system-on-chip designs. But when new technology comes out, it comes in the form of an external modem which will eventually get integrated in a future SoC. So in 2019 and 2020, 4G/LTE phones don’t have an external modem, 5G phones often do. But Apple doesn’t have their own modem technology (they bought Intel’s earlier this year, but it’s not ready yet). So they’ve always had an external cellular modem. In fact, they were Intel’s last major customer, which is why Apple pretty much had to get in-house cellular modem technology… there’s no guarantee you’ll always get what you want as an external component. So going to 5G-NR is not any different than what Apple’s done in the past. Sure, any 5G radio system is more power hungry, with more antennas and other components in addition to all the hardware you already had to support 3G and 4G.  It’s actually, in a weird way, a good branding move, too. Even after Apple started supporting fast charging (USB Power Delivery) in the iPhone, they still shipped with the low power 5W power adapters. So users did not routinely see fast charging, and they didn’t necessarily experience wireless charging. Now, while some users will stick with “whatever they used for the previous iPhone”, others will buy new power bricks or wireless pads. I wouldn’t be surprised if Apple discontinues their cheap 5W device, but even if they don’t, they have the opportunity to sell you on fast charging without having to spend 3x as much to drop it in the box, and if you buy a cheaper 3rd party unit and it doesn’t perform, well, it’s not the iPhone’s fault. Same idea with earbuds… they ship with awful quality earbuds, and that’s what most users are listening through…. those who listen. Everyone else drops the earbuds in a drawer, eventually they work their way to landfills. If you’re paying for some kind of earbud or headphone, same quality issues: buy the pricey one from Apple or you’re to blame for bad sound. Not Apple.

The two gentlemen who answered the question before me don't seem to be getting the “USB-C” part. I'll elaborate. Traditionally all the iPhones were shipped with USB-A to Lightning cable and a USB-A charging brick.   The exception was the iPhone 11 where it was shipped with a Lightning to USB-C cable and a USB-C charging brick.  The problem arises here. The iPhone 12 comes with a Lightning to USB-C cable but the only people who have these adapters are those who own the iPhone 11 series. But they are unlikely to upgrade to the 12 series (exceptions exist in every scenario). The people who buy the iPhone 12 series will then have to buy a seperate USB-C adapter which costs about 20$ (₹1900 in India) plus shipping. The Magsafe one costs 39$ (₹2900 in India) plus shipping (All prices are offiicial prices from Apple store). To the people who say I could just use an old adapter and cable, sure you could, but you wouldn't get the 20W fast charging then. You'll get a standard 5W output. Now coming to the actual question "How does Apple get away with this?" Simple answer? Because they can! And the millions of Apple fans will still buy it! (No offence). The environment aspect was just a cover up. Apple removed the charging brick so that they can promote the new MagSafe charger, very similar to how they removed the headphone jack to increase sales of AirPods. There are many leaks already that the iPhone 13 will not have ANY charging port and will completely move to wireless charging, thus forcing people to buy the MagSafe charger extra on top of the iPhone. With this they not only save huge amounts on cost and shipping but also drastically increase revenue from sales of the new products. I mean, when you run out of ideas to gouge customers, you have to go lower and lower. Remember the 1000$ stand and the 700$ wheels?? Sure its a bummer for the public, but a great way of taking advantage of millions of Apple fans. Bomus! Here's a Dad-joke- Q- why did Apple remove the charger and earbuds from the box? A- Because they like to think Out-of-the-box! I've managed to earn an eye-roll from you!
